The **Houston Astros** are an American [professional
baseball](/wiki/Professional_baseball "Professional baseball") team based in
[Houston, Texas](/wiki/Houston "Houston"). The Astros compete in [Major League
Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League Baseball") (MLB) as a
member club of the [American League](/wiki/American_League "American League")
(AL) [West](/wiki/American_League_West "American League West") division,
having moved to the division in 2013 after spending their first 51 seasons in
the [National League](/wiki/National_League "National League") (NL).[2][3] The
Astros have played their home games at [Minute Maid
Park](/wiki/Minute_Maid_Park "Minute Maid Park") since
[2000](/wiki/2000_Major_League_Baseball_season "2000 Major League Baseball
season").[4]

The Astros were established as the **Houston Colt .45s** and entered the
National League as an expansion team in
[1962](/wiki/1962_Major_League_Baseball_season "1962 Major League Baseball
season") along with the [New York Mets](/wiki/New_York_Mets "New York Mets").
The current name—reflecting Houston's role as the control center of the U.S.
[space program](/wiki/NASA "NASA")—was adopted three years later, when they
moved into the [Astrodome](/wiki/Astrodome "Astrodome"), the world's first
domed sports stadium.

The Astros played in the NL from 1962 to 2012. They played in the
[West](/wiki/National_League_West "National League West") Division from 1969
to 1993, and the [Central](/wiki/National_League_Central "National League
Central") Division from 1994 to 2012. While a member of the NL, the Astros
played in one [World Series](/wiki/World_Series "World Series"), in
[2005](/wiki/2005_World_Series "2005 World Series"), against the [Chicago
White Sox](/wiki/Chicago_White_Sox "Chicago White Sox"), in which they were
swept in four games. In 2017, they became the first franchise in MLB history
to have won a pennant in both the NL and the AL, when they defeated the [New
York Yankees](/wiki/New_York_Yankees "New York Yankees") in the
[ALCS](/wiki/2017_American_League_Championship_Series "2017 American League
Championship Series"). They subsequently won the [2017 World
Series](/wiki/2017_World_Series "2017 World Series") against the [Los Angeles
Dodgers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Dodgers "Los Angeles Dodgers"), winning four games
to three, earning the team, and Texas, its first World Series title.

## Franchise
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Franchise history")]

### Major League Baseball comes to
Texas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Major League Baseball comes to Texas")]

See also: [Houston Buffaloes](/wiki/Houston_Buffaloes "Houston Buffaloes")

From 1888 until 1961, Houston's professional baseball club was the minor
league [Houston Buffaloes](/wiki/Houston_Buffaloes "Houston Buffaloes").
Although expansion from the [National League](/wiki/National_League "National
League") eventually brought an MLB team to Texas in
[1962](/wiki/1962_Major_League_Baseball_season "1962 Major League Baseball
season"), Houston officials had been making efforts to do so for years
prior.[5] There were four men chiefly responsible for bringing Major League
Baseball to Houston: George Kirksey and Craig Cullinan, who had led a futile
attempt to purchase the [St. Louis Cardinals](/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St.
Louis Cardinals") in 1952; R.E. "Bob" Smith, a prominent oilman and real
estate magnate in Houston who was brought in for his financial resources; and
Judge [Roy Hofheinz](/wiki/Roy_Hofheinz "Roy Hofheinz"), a former Mayor of
Houston and Harris County Judge who was recruited for his salesmanship and
political style. They formed the Houston Sports Association as their vehicle
for attaining a big league franchise for the city of Houston.[6]

Given MLB's refusal to consider expansion, Kirksey, Cullinan, Smith, and
Hofheinz joined forces with would-be owners from other cities and announced
the formation of a new league to compete with the established National and
American Leagues. They called the new league the [Continental
League](/wiki/Continental_League "Continental League"). Wanting to protect
potential new markets, both existing leagues chose to expand from eight teams
to ten. However, plans eventually fell through for the Houston franchise after
the Houston Buffaloes owner, [Marty Marion](/wiki/Marty_Marion "Marty
Marion"), could not come to an agreement with the HSA to sell the team.[7] To
make matters worse, the Continental League as a whole folded in August 1960.

However, on October 17, 1960, the [National League](/wiki/National_League
"National League") [granted an expansion
franchise](/wiki/1962_Major_League_Baseball_expansion "1962 Major League
Baseball expansion") to the Houston Sports Association in which their team
could begin play in the 1962 season. According to the [Major League Baseball
Constitution](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_Constitution "Major League Baseball
Constitution"), the Houston Sports Association was required to obtain
territorial rights from the Houston Buffaloes in order to play in the Houston
area, and again negotiations began to purchase the team.[8][9] Eventually, the
Houston Sports Association succeeded in purchasing the Houston Buffaloes, at
this point majority-owned by William Hopkins, on January 17, 1961.[10] The
Buffs played one last minor league season as the top farm team of the [Chicago
Cubs](/wiki/Chicago_Cubs "Chicago Cubs") in 1961 before being succeeded by the
city's NL club.

The new Houston team was named the Colt .45s after a "Name The Team" contest
was won by William Irving Neder. The [Colt .45](/wiki/Colt_Single_Action_Army
"Colt Single Action Army") was well known as "the gun that won the west."[11]
The colors selected were navy blue and orange. The first team was formed
mostly through an [expansion
draft](/wiki/1961_Major_League_Baseball_expansion_draft "1961 Major League
Baseball expansion draft") after the 1961 season. The Colt .45s and their
expansion cousins, the [New York Mets](/wiki/New_York_Mets "New York Mets"),
took turns choosing players left unprotected by the other National League
franchises.

Many of those associated with the Houston Buffaloes organization were allowed
by the ownership to continue in the major league. Manager [Harry
Craft](/wiki/Harry_Craft "Harry Craft"), who had joined Houston in 1961,
remained in the same position for the team until the end of the [1964
season](/wiki/1964_Houston_Colt_.45s_season "1964 Houston Colt .45s season").
General manager [Spec Richardson](/wiki/Spec_Richardson "Spec Richardson")
also continued with the organization as business manager, but was later
promoted again to the same position with the Astros from 1967 until 1975.
Although most players for the major league franchise were obtained through the
[1961 Major League Baseball expansion
draft](/wiki/1961_Major_League_Baseball_expansion_draft "1961 Major League
Baseball expansion draft"), Buffs players [J.C. Hartman](/wiki/J.C._Hartman
"J.C. Hartman"), [Pidge Browne](/wiki/Pidge_Browne "Pidge Browne"), [Jim
Campbell](/wiki/Jim_Campbell_\(catcher\) "Jim Campbell \(catcher\)"), [Ron
Davis](/wiki/Ron_Davis_\(outfielder\) "Ron Davis \(outfielder\)"), [Dave
Giusti](/wiki/Dave_Giusti "Dave Giusti"), and [Dave
Roberts](/wiki/Dave_Roberts_\(first_baseman\) "Dave Roberts \(first
baseman\)") were chosen to continue as major league ball players.

Similarly, the radio broadcasting team remained with the new Houston major
league franchise. Loel Passe worked alongside [Gene Elston](/wiki/Gene_Elston
"Gene Elston") as a color commentator until he retired from broadcasting in
1976. Elston continued with the Astros until 1986.

The Colt .45s began their existence playing at [Colt
Stadium](/wiki/Colt_Stadium "Colt Stadium"), a temporary venue built just
north of the construction site of the indoor stadium.

### 1962–1964: The Colt
.45s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: 1962–1964: The Colt .45s")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/ce/HOU_1094.gif/220px-
HOU_1094.gif)](/wiki/File:HOU_1094.gif)

[](/wiki/File:HOU_1094.gif "Enlarge")

Colt .45s logo, 1962–1964

The Colt .45s started their inaugural season on April 10, 1962, against the
[Chicago Cubs](/wiki/1962_Chicago_Cubs_season "1962 Chicago Cubs season") with
[Harry Craft](/wiki/Harry_Craft "Harry Craft") as the Colt .45s' manager. [Bob
Aspromonte](/wiki/Bob_Aspromonte "Bob Aspromonte") scored the first run for
the Colt .45s on an [Al Spangler](/wiki/Al_Spangler "Al Spangler") triple in
the first inning.[12] They started the season with a three-game sweep of the
Cubs but eventually finished eighth among the National League's ten teams. The
team's best pitcher, [Richard "Turk" Farrell](/wiki/Turk_Farrell "Turk
Farrell"), lost 20 games despite an [ERA](/wiki/Earned_run_average "Earned run
average") of 3.02. A starter for the Colt .45s, Farrell was primarily a relief
pitcher prior to playing for Houston. He was selected to both All-Star Games
in 1962.[13]

The 1963 season saw more young talent mixed with seasoned veterans. [Jimmy
Wynn](/wiki/Jimmy_Wynn "Jimmy Wynn"), [Rusty Staub](/wiki/Rusty_Staub "Rusty
Staub"), and [Joe Morgan](/wiki/Joe_Morgan "Joe Morgan") all made their major
league debuts in the [1963 season](/wiki/1963_Major_League_Baseball_season
"1963 Major League Baseball season"). However, Houston's position in the
standings did not improve. In fact, the Colt .45s finished in ninth place with
a 66–96 record. The team was still building, trying to find that perfect mix
to compete.[6] The 1964 campaign began on a sad note, as relief pitcher [Jim
Umbricht](/wiki/Jim_Umbricht "Jim Umbricht") died of cancer at the age of 33
on April 8, just before [Opening Day](/wiki/Opening_Day "Opening Day").[14]
Umbricht was the only Colt .45s pitcher to post a winning record in Houston's
first two seasons. He was so well liked by players and fans that the team
retired his jersey number, 32, in 1965.[15]

Just on the horizon, the structure of the new domed stadium was more prevalent
and it would soon change the way that baseball was watched in Houston and
around the league. On December 1, 1964, the team announced the name change
from Colt .45s to "Astros."[16][17][18]

### 1965–1970: The Great
Indoors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: 1965–1970: The Great Indoors")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/ec/HOU_1093.gif/220px-
HOU_1093.gif)](/wiki/File:HOU_1093.gif)

[](/wiki/File:HOU_1093.gif "Enlarge")

Astros logo, 1965–1974 with the Astrodome

With Judge [Roy Hofheinz](/wiki/Roy_Hofheinz "Roy Hofheinz") now the sole
owner of the franchise and the new venue complete, the renamed "Astros" moved
into their new domed stadium, the [_Astro_ dome](/wiki/Astrodome "Astrodome"),
in 1965. The name honored Houston's position as the center of the nation's
space program; [NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA")'s new [Manned Spacecraft
Center](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson_Space_Center "Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center")
had recently opened southeast of the city. The Astrodome, coined the "Eighth
Wonder of the World", did little to improve the home team's results on the
field. While several "indoor" firsts were accomplished, the team still
finished ninth in the standings. The attendance was high not because of the
team accomplishments, but because people came from miles around to see the
Astrodome.

Just as the excitement was settling down over the Astrodome, the [1966
season](/wiki/1966_Major_League_Baseball_season "1966 Major League Baseball
season") found something new to put the domed stadium in the spotlight once
again – the field. Grass would not grow in the new park, since the roof panels
had been painted to reduce the glare that was causing players on both the
Astros and the visiting teams to miss routine pop flies. A new artificial turf
was created called "[AstroTurf](/wiki/AstroTurf "AstroTurf")" and Houston
would be involved in yet another change in the way the game was played.[19]

With new manager [Grady Hatton](/wiki/Grady_Hatton "Grady Hatton") the Astros
started the 1966 season strong. By May they were in second place in the
National League and looked like a team that could contend. [Joe
Morgan](/wiki/Joe_Morgan "Joe Morgan") was named as a starter on the [All-Star
Team](/wiki/1966_Major_League_Baseball_All-Star_Game "1966 Major League
Baseball All-Star Game"). The success did not last as they lost [Jimmy
Wynn](/wiki/Jimmy_Wynn "Jimmy Wynn") for the season after he crashed into an
outfield fence in [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia") and Morgan
had broken his knee cap.[6] [1967](/wiki/1967_Houston_Astros_season "1967
Houston Astros season") saw first baseman [Eddie Mathews](/wiki/Eddie_Mathews
"Eddie Mathews") join the Astros. The slugger hit his 500th home run while in
Houston. He would be traded late in the season and [Doug
Rader](/wiki/Doug_Rader "Doug Rader") would be promoted to the big leagues.
Rookie [Don Wilson](/wiki/Don_Wilson_\(baseball\) "Don Wilson \(baseball\)")
pitched a no-hitter on June 18. Wynn also provided some enthusiasm in 1967.
The 5 ft 9 in Wynn was becoming known not only for how often he hit home runs,
but also for how far he hit them. Wynn set club records with 37 home runs, and
107 RBIs. It was also in 1967 that Wynn hit his famous home run onto
[Interstate 75](/wiki/Interstate_75 "Interstate 75") in
[Cincinnati](/wiki/Cincinnati "Cincinnati").[20] As the season came to a
close, the Astros found themselves again in ninth place and with a winning
percentage below .500. The team looked good on paper, but could not make it
work on the field.

April 15, 1968 saw a pitching duel for the ages. The Astros' [Don
Wilson](/wiki/Don_Wilson_\(baseball\) "Don Wilson \(baseball\)") and the Mets'
[Tom Seaver](/wiki/Tom_Seaver "Tom Seaver") faced each other in a pitching
duel that lasted six hours. Seaver went ten innings, allowing no walks and
just two hits. Wilson went nine innings, allowing five hits and three walks.
After the starters exited, eleven relievers (seven for the Mets and four for
the Astros) tried to end the game. The game finally ended in the 24th inning
when Aspromonte hit a shot toward Mets shortstop [Al Weis](/wiki/Al_Weis "Al
Weis"). Weis had been perfect all night at short, but he was not quick enough
to make the play. The ball zipped into left field, allowing [Norm
Miller](/wiki/Norm_Miller_\(baseball\) "Norm Miller \(baseball\)") to
score.[21]

With baseball expansion and trades, the Astros had dramatically changed in
[1969](/wiki/1969_Houston_Astros_season "1969 Houston Astros season").
Aspromonte was sent to the Braves and Staub was traded to the expansion
[Montreal Expos](/wiki/Montreal_Expos "Montreal Expos"), in exchange for
outfielder [Jesús Alou](/wiki/Jes%C3%BAs_Alou "Jesús Alou") and first baseman
[Donn Clendenon](/wiki/Donn_Clendenon "Donn Clendenon"). However, Clendenon
refused to report to Houston, electing to retire and take job with a pen
manufacturing company. The Astros asked Commissioner Bowie Kuhn to void the
trade, but he refused. Instead, he awarded Jack Billingham and a left-handed
relief pitcher to the Astros to complete the trade. Cuellar was traded to the
[Baltimore Orioles](/wiki/Baltimore_Orioles "Baltimore Orioles") for [Curt
Blefary](/wiki/Curt_Blefary "Curt Blefary"). Other new players included
catcher [Johnny Edwards](/wiki/Johnny_Edwards_\(baseball\) "Johnny Edwards
\(baseball\)"), infielder [Denis Menke](/wiki/Denis_Menke "Denis Menke"), and
pitcher [Denny Lemaster](/wiki/Denny_Lemaster "Denny Lemaster"). Wilson
continued to pitch brilliantly and on May 1 threw the second no-hitter of his
career. In that game, he struck out 18 batters, tying what was then the all-
time single-game mark. He was just 24 years of age and was second to only
[Sandy Koufax](/wiki/Sandy_Koufax "Sandy Koufax") for career no-hit wins.
Wilson's no-hitter lit the Astros' fire after a miserable month of April, and
six days later the team tied a major league record by turning seven double
plays in a game. By May's end the Astros had put together a ten-game winning
streak. The Houston infield tandem of Menke and Joe Morgan continued to
improve, providing power at the plate and great defense. Morgan had 15 homers
and stole 49 bases while Menke led the Astros with 90 RBIs. The Menke/Morgan
punch was beginning to come alive, and the team was responding to Walker's
management style. The Astros dominated the season series against their
expansion twins, the New York Mets, that season. In one game at New York,
Denis Menke and Jimmy Wynn hit [grand slams](/wiki/Grand_slam_\(baseball\)
"Grand slam \(baseball\)") in the same inning, against a Mets team that would
go on to win the World Series that same year. The Astros finished the 1969
season with a record of 81 wins, 81 losses, marking their first season of .500
ball.

In [1970](/wiki/1970_Houston_Astros_season "1970 Houston Astros season"), the
Astros were expected to be a serious threat in the National League West. In
June, 19-year-old [César Cedeño](/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Cede%C3%B1o "César Cedeño")
was called up and immediately showed signs of being a superstar. The Dominican
outfielder batted .310 after being called up. Not to be outdone, [Denis
Menke](/wiki/Denis_Menke "Denis Menke") batted .304 and [Jesús
Alou](/wiki/Jes%C3%BAs_Alou "Jesús Alou") batted .306. The Astros' batting
average was up by 19 points compared to the season before.[20][22] The team
looked good, but the Astros' ERA was up. [Larry Dierker](/wiki/Larry_Dierker
"Larry Dierker") and [Don Wilson](/wiki/Don_Wilson_\(baseball\) "Don Wilson
\(baseball\)") had winning records, but the pitching staff as a whole had an
off season. Houston finished in fourth place in 1970.

### 1971–1974: The boys in
orange[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: 1971–1974: The boys in orange")]

The fashion trends of the 1970s had started taking root in baseball. Long hair
and loud colors were starting to appear on team uniforms, including the
Astros'. In 1971 the Astros made some changes to their uniform: they kept the
same style they had in previous seasons, but inverted the colors. What was
navy blue was now orange and what was orange was now a lighter shade of blue.
The players' last names were added to the back of the jerseys. In 1972, the
uniform fabric was also changed to what was at the time revolutionizing the
industry – polyester. Belts were replaced by elastic waistbands, and jerseys
zipped up instead of having buttons. The uniforms became popular with fans,
but would last only until 1975, when the Astros would shock baseball and the
fashion world.[23]

The uniforms were about the only thing that did change in 1971. The
acquisition of [Roger Metzger](/wiki/Roger_Metzger "Roger Metzger") from the
[Chicago Cubs](/wiki/Chicago_Cubs "Chicago Cubs") in the off-season moved
Menke to first base and [Bob Watson](/wiki/Bob_Watson "Bob Watson") to the
outfield. The Astros got off to a slow start and the pitching and hitting
averages were down. [Larry Dierker](/wiki/Larry_Dierker "Larry Dierker") was
selected to the All-Star game in 1971, but due to an arm injury he could not
make it. [César Cedeño](/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Cede%C3%B1o "César Cedeño") led the
club with 81 RBIs and the league with 40 doubles, but batted just .264 and had
102 strikeouts in his second season with the Astros.[24] Pitcher [J. R.
Richard](/wiki/J._R._Richard "J. R. Richard") made his debut in September of
the 1971 season against the [Giants](/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants "San Francisco
Giants").

#### The Big
Trade[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: The Big Trade")]

See also: [The Big Red Machine](/wiki/The_Big_Red_Machine "The Big Red
Machine")

In November [1971](/wiki/1971_Houston_Astros_season "1971 Houston Astros
season") the Astros and [Cincinnati Reds](/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds "Cincinnati
Reds") made one of the biggest blockbuster trades in the history of the
sport,[25] and helped create The Big Red Machine of the 1970s,[26] with the
Reds getting the better end of the deal. Houston sent second baseman [Joe
Morgan](/wiki/Joe_Morgan "Joe Morgan"), infielder [Denis
Menke](/wiki/Denis_Menke "Denis Menke"), pitcher [Jack
Billingham](/wiki/Jack_Billingham "Jack Billingham"), outfielder [César
Gerónimo](/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Ger%C3%B3nimo "César Gerónimo") and prospect [Ed
Armbrister](/wiki/Ed_Armbrister "Ed Armbrister") to Cincinnati for first
baseman [Lee May](/wiki/Lee_May "Lee May"), second baseman [Tommy
Helms](/wiki/Tommy_Helms "Tommy Helms") and infielder [Jimmy
Stewart](/wiki/Jimmy_Stewart_\(baseball\) "Jimmy Stewart \(baseball\)"). The
trade left Astros fans and the baseball world scratching their heads as to why
[General Manager](/wiki/General_manager_\(baseball\) "General manager
\(baseball\)") [Spec Richardson](/wiki/Spec_Richardson "Spec Richardson")
would give up so much for so little. The Reds, on the other hand, would shore
up many problems. They had an off year in 1971, but were the National League
Pennant winner in [1972](/wiki/1972_Cincinnati_Reds_season "1972 Cincinnati
Reds season").[25]

The Astros' acquisition of Lee May added more power to the lineup in
[1972](/wiki/1972_Houston_Astros_season "1972 Houston Astros season"). May,
Wynn, Rader and Cedeño all had 20 or more home runs and Watson hit 16. Cedeño
also led the Astros with a .320 batting average, 55 stolen bases and made
spectacular plays on the field. Cedeño made his first All-Star game in 1972
and became the first Astros player in team history to hit for the cycle in
August versus the Reds. The Astros finished the strike-shortened season at
84-69, their first winning season.[6]

Astros fans had hoped for more of the same in
[1973](/wiki/1973_Major_League_Baseball_season "1973 Major League Baseball
season"), but it was not to be. The Astros run production was down, even
though the same five sluggers the year before were still punching the ball out
of the park. Lee May led the Astros with 28 home runs and Cesar Cedeño batted
.320 with 25 home runs. [Bob Watson](/wiki/Bob_Watson "Bob Watson") hit the
.312 mark and drove in 94 runs. [Doug Rader](/wiki/Doug_Rader "Doug Rader")
and [Jimmy Wynn](/wiki/Jimmy_Wynn "Jimmy Wynn") both had 20 or more home runs.
However, injuries to their pitching staff limited the Astros to an 82–80
fourth-place finish. The Astros again finished in fourth place the next year
under new manager [Preston Gómez](/wiki/Preston_G%C3%B3mez "Preston
Gómez").[6][27]

### 1975–1979: The rainbow
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: 1975–1979: The rainbow era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Houston_Astros_logo.gif/220px-
Houston_Astros_logo.gif)](/wiki/File:Houston_Astros_logo.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Houston_Astros_logo.gif "Enlarge")

Astros logo, 1975–1993 with the Astrodome

With the $38 million deficit of the Astrodome, control of the
Astrodomain[_[further explanation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify
"Wikipedia:Please clarify")_] was passed from Judge [Roy
Hofheinz](/wiki/Roy_Hofheinz "Roy Hofheinz") to GE Credit and Ford Motor
Credit. This included the Astros. The creditors were just interested in
preserving asset value of the team, so any money spent had to be found or
saved somewhere else.[28] [Tal Smith](/wiki/Tal_Smith "Tal Smith") returned to
the Astros from the [New York Yankees](/wiki/New_York_Yankees "New York
Yankees") to find a team that needed a lot of work and did not have a lot of
money. However, there would be some bright spots that would prove to be good
investments in the near future.

The year started on a sad note. Pitcher Don Wilson was found dead in the
passenger seat of his car on January 5, 1975. Cause of death was asphyxiation
by carbon monoxide. Wilson was 29 years old. Wilson's number 40 was retired on
April 13, 1975.[23]

The 1975 season saw the introduction of the Astros' new uniforms. Many teams
were going away from the traditional uniform and the Astros were no exception.
The uniforms had multishade stripes of orange, red and yellow in front and in
back behind a large dark blue star over the midsection. The same stripes ran
down the pant legs. Players numbers not only appeared on the back of the
jersey, but also on the pant leg. The bright stripes were meant to appear as a
fiery trail like a rocket sweeping across the heavens. The uniforms were
panned by critics, but the public liked them and versions started appearing at
the high school and little league level. The uniform was so different from
what other teams wore that the Astros wore it both at home and on the road
until 1980.[23]

Besides the bright new uniforms there were some other changes. [Lee
May](/wiki/Lee_May "Lee May") was traded to
[Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore_Orioles "Baltimore Orioles") for much talked about
rookie second baseman [Rob Andrews](/wiki/Rob_Andrews_\(baseball\) "Rob
Andrews \(baseball\)") and utility player [Enos Cabell](/wiki/Enos_Cabell
"Enos Cabell"). In Baltimore, Cabell was stuck behind third baseman [Brooks
Robinson](/wiki/Brooks_Robinson "Brooks Robinson"), but he took advantage of
his opportunity in Houston and became their everyday third baseman.[29] Cabell
would go on to become a big part of the team's success in later years. With
May gone, [Bob Watson](/wiki/Bob_Watson "Bob Watson") was able to move to
first base and was a bright spot in the line up, batting .324 with 85 RBI.

The two biggest moves the Astros made in the offseason were the acquisitions
of [Joe Niekro](/wiki/Joe_Niekro "Joe Niekro") and [José
Cruz](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Cruz "José Cruz"). The Astros bought Niekro from the
[Braves](/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta Braves") for almost nothing. Niekro had
bounced around the big leagues with minimal success. His older brother [Phil
Niekro](/wiki/Phil_Niekro "Phil Niekro") had started teaching Joe how to throw
his knuckleball and Joe was just starting to use it when he came to the
Astros. Niekro won six games, saved four games and had an ERA of 3.07.[30]
[José Cruz](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Cruz "José Cruz") was also a steal, in retrospect,
from the [Cardinals](/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis Cardinals").[31]
Cruz became a fixture in the Astros' outfield for several years and would
eventually have his number 25 retired.

Despite high expectations, [1975](/wiki/1975_Houston_Astros_season "1975
Houston Astros season") was among the Astros' worst in franchise history.
Their record of 64–97 was far worse than even the expansion Colt .45's and
would remain the worst record in franchise history until
[2011](/wiki/2011_Houston_Astros_season "2011 Houston Astros season"). It was
the worst record in baseball and manager [Preston
Gómez](/wiki/Preston_G%C3%B3mez "Preston Gómez") was fired late in the season
and replaced by [Bill Virdon](/wiki/Bill_Virdon "Bill Virdon"). The Astros
played .500 ball under Virdon in the last 34 games of the season.[23] With
Virdon as the manager the Astros improved greatly in 1976 finishing in third
place with an 80–82 record. A healthy [César
Cedeño](/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Cede%C3%B1o "César Cedeño") was a key reason for the
Astros' success in 1976. [Bob Watson](/wiki/Bob_Watson "Bob Watson") continued
to show consistency and led the club with a .313 average and 102 RBI. [José
Cruz](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Cruz "José Cruz") became Houston's everyday left fielder
and hit .303 with 28 stolen bases.[32][33] 1976 saw the end of [Larry
Dierker](/wiki/Larry_Dierker "Larry Dierker")'s playing career as an Astro,
but before it was all over he would throw a no-hitter and win the 1,000th game
in the Astrodome.[34] The Astros finished in third place again in
[1977](/wiki/1977_Houston_Astros_season "1977 Houston Astros season") with a
record of 81–81.[23]

One of the big problems the Astros had in the late 1970s was that they were
unable to compete in the free agent market. Ford Motor Credit Company was
still in control of the team and was looking to sell the Astros, but they were
not going to spend money on better players. Most of the talent was either farm
grown or bought on the cheap.

The [1979 season](/wiki/1979_Houston_Astros_season "1979 Houston Astros
season") would prove to be a big turnaround in Astros history. During the
offseason, the Astros made an effort to fix some of their problem areas. They
traded [Floyd Bannister](/wiki/Floyd_Bannister "Floyd Bannister") to
[Seattle](/wiki/Seattle_Mariners "Seattle Mariners") for shortstop [Craig
Reynolds](/wiki/Craig_Reynolds_\(baseball\) "Craig Reynolds \(baseball\)") and
acquired catcher [Alan Ashby](/wiki/Alan_Ashby "Alan Ashby") from
[Toronto](/wiki/Toronto_Blue_Jays "Toronto Blue Jays") for pitcher [Mark
Lemongello](/wiki/Mark_Lemongello "Mark Lemongello"). Reynolds and Ashby were
both solid in their positions and gave Houston some much needed
consistency.[35] The season started with a boost from pitcher [Ken
Forsch](/wiki/Ken_Forsch "Ken Forsch"), who threw a [no-hitter](/wiki/No-
hitter "No-hitter") the [Braves](/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta Braves") the
second game of the season.[23] In May 1979, New Jersey shipping tycoon Dr.
[John McMullen](/wiki/John_McMullen_\(engineer\) "John McMullen \(engineer\)")
had agreed to buy the Astros. Now with an investor in charge, the Astros would
be more likely to compete in the free agent market.[36]

The Astros were playing great baseball throughout the season. [José
Cruz](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Cruz "José Cruz") and [Enos Cabell](/wiki/Enos_Cabell
"Enos Cabell") both stole 30 bases. [Joe Niekro](/wiki/Joe_Niekro "Joe
Niekro") had a great year with 21 wins and 3.00 ERA. [J. R.
Richard](/wiki/J._R._Richard "J. R. Richard") won 18 games and set a new
personal strikeout record at 313. [Joe Sambito](/wiki/Joe_Sambito "Joe
Sambito") came into his own with 22 saves as the Astros closer. Things were
going as they should for a team that could win the west.[23] The Astros and
Reds battled the final month of the season. The Reds pulled ahead of the
Astros by a game and a half. Later that month they split a pair and the Reds
kept the lead. That would be how it would end. The Astros finished with their
best record to that point at 89–73 and 1½ games behind the NL winner Reds.[23]

With Dr. McMullen as sole owner of the Astros, the team would now benefit in
ways a corporation could not give them. The rumors of the Astros moving out of
Houston started to crumble and the Astros were now able to compete in the
free-agent market. McMullen showed the city of Houston that he too wanted a
winning team, signing nearby [Alvin, Texas](/wiki/Alvin,_Texas "Alvin, Texas")
native [Nolan Ryan](/wiki/Nolan_Ryan "Nolan Ryan") to the first million-
dollar-a-year deal. Ryan had four career no-hitters already and had struck out
383 in one season.[23]

### 1980: On the
Brink[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: 1980: On the Brink")]

[Joe Morgan](/wiki/Joe_Morgan "Joe Morgan") returned in 1980. Now back in
Houston with two MVP awards and two [World Series
rings](/wiki/World_Series_ring "World Series ring"), Morgan wanted to help
make the Astros a pennant winner.

The 1980 pitching staff was one of the best Houston ever had, with the
fastball of Ryan, the knuckleball of [Joe Niekro](/wiki/Joe_Niekro "Joe
Niekro") and the terrifying 6 ft 8 in frame of [J. R.
Richard](/wiki/J._R._Richard "J. R. Richard"). Teams felt lucky to face [Ken
Forsch](/wiki/Ken_Forsch "Ken Forsch"), who was a double-digit winner in the
previous two seasons. Richard became the first Astros pitcher to start an All-
Star game. After a medical examination three days later, Richard was told to
rest his arm and he collapsed during a July 30 workout. He had suffered a
stroke after a blood clot in the arm apparently moved to his neck and cut off
blood flow to the brain. Surgery was done to save his life, but the Astros had
lost their ace pitcher after a 10–4 start with a stingy 1.89 ERA. Richard
attempted a comeback, but would never again pitch a big league game.[23][37]

After the loss of Richard and some offensive struggles, the Astros slipped to
third place in the division behind the Dodgers and the Reds. They bounced back
to first with a ten-game winning streak, but the Dodgers had regained a two-
game lead when they arrived in Houston on September 9. The Astros won the
first two games of that series and the two teams were tied for the division
lead. The Astros held a three-game lead over the Dodgers with three games left
in the season against the Dodgers. The Dodgers swept the series games, forcing
a one-game playoff the next day.[38] The Astros would however win the one-game
playoff 7-1, and advance to their first post-season.

The team would face the [Philadelphia Phillies](/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies
"Philadelphia Phillies") in the [1980 National League Championship
Series](/wiki/1980_National_League_Championship_Series "1980 National League
Championship Series"). The Phillies sent out [Steve
Carlton](/wiki/Steve_Carlton "Steve Carlton") in game one of the NLCS after a
six-hour flight the night before.[23][39] The Phillies would win the opener
after the Astros got out to a 1-0 third-inning lead. Ken Forsch pitched
particularly strong fourth and fifth innings, but [Greg
Luzinski](/wiki/Greg_Luzinski "Greg Luzinski") hit a sixth-inning two-run bomb
to the 300 level seats of [Veterans Stadium](/wiki/Veterans_Stadium "Veterans
Stadium"). The Phillies added an insurance run on the way to a 3–1 win.[6]
Houston bounced back to win games two and three. Game four went into extra
innings, with the Phillies taking the lead and the win in the tenth inning.
[Pete Rose](/wiki/Pete_Rose "Pete Rose") started a rally with a one-out
single, then Luzinski doubled off the left field wall and Rose bowled over
catcher Bruce Bochy to score the go-ahead run. The Phillies got an insurance
run on the way to tying the series.[6]

Rookie Phillies pitcher [Marty Bystrom](/wiki/Marty_Bystrom "Marty Bystrom")
was sent out by Philadelphia manager [Dallas
Green](/wiki/Dallas_Green_\(baseball\) "Dallas Green \(baseball\)") to face
veteran [Nolan Ryan](/wiki/Nolan_Ryan "Nolan Ryan") in Game Five. The rookie
gave up a run in the first inning, then held the Astros at bay until the sixth
inning. An Astros lead was lost when [Bob Boone](/wiki/Bob_Boone "Bob Boone")
hit a two-out single in the second, but the Astros tied the game in the sixth
with an [Alan Ashby](/wiki/Alan_Ashby "Alan Ashby") single scoring [Denny
Walling](/wiki/Denny_Walling "Denny Walling"). Houston took a 5–2 lead in the
seventh, however the Phillies came back with five runs in the inning. The
Astros came back against [Tug McGraw](/wiki/Tug_McGraw "Tug McGraw") with four
singles and two two-out runs. Now in extra innings, [Garry
Maddox](/wiki/Garry_Maddox "Garry Maddox") doubled in [Del
Unser](/wiki/Del_Unser "Del Unser") with one out to give the Phillies an 8–7
lead. The Astros failed to score in the bottom of the tenth.[6][40]

### 1981–1985[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: 1981–1985")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Nolan_Ryan_in_Atlanta_close-
up.jpg/220px-Nolan_Ryan_in_Atlanta_close-
up.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nolan_Ryan_in_Atlanta_close-up.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Nolan_Ryan_in_Atlanta_close-up.jpg "Enlarge")

Astros starting pitcher [Nolan Ryan](/wiki/Nolan_Ryan "Nolan Ryan") in 1983

A 1981 player strike ran between June 12 and August 10. Ultimately, the strike
would help the Astros get into the playoffs. [Nolan Ryan](/wiki/Nolan_Ryan
"Nolan Ryan") and [Bob Knepper](/wiki/Bob_Knepper "Bob Knepper") picked up
steam in the second half of the season. Ryan threw his fifth no-hitter on
September 26 and finished the season with a 1.69 ERA. Knepper finished with an
ERA of 2.18.[6] In the wake of the strike, Major League Baseball took the
winners of each "half" season and set up a best-of-five divisional playoff.
The [Reds](/wiki/1981_Cincinnati_Reds_season "1981 Cincinnati Reds season")
won more games than any other team in the National League, but they won
neither half of the strike-divided season. The
[Astros](/wiki/1981_Houston_Astros_season "1981 Houston Astros season")
finished 61–49 overall, which would have been third in the division behind the
Reds and the [Dodgers](/wiki/1981_Los_Angeles_Dodgers_season "1981 Los Angeles
Dodgers season"). Advancing to the playoffs as winners of the second half,
Houston beat Los Angeles in their first two playoff games at home, but the
Dodgers took the next three in Los Angeles to advance to the
[NLCS](/wiki/1981_National_League_Championship_Series "1981 National League
Championship Series").

By [1982](/wiki/1982_Houston_Astros_season "1982 Houston Astros season"), only
four players and three starting pitchers remained from the 1980 squad. The
Astros were out of pennant contention by August and began rebuilding for the
near future. [Bill Virdon](/wiki/Bill_Virdon "Bill Virdon") was fired as
manager and replaced by original Colt .45 [Bob Lillis](/wiki/Bob_Lillis "Bob
Lillis"). [Don Sutton](/wiki/Don_Sutton "Don Sutton") asked to be traded and
was sent to the [Milwaukee Brewers](/wiki/Milwaukee_Brewers "Milwaukee
Brewers") for cash and the team gained three new prospects, including [Kevin
Bass](/wiki/Kevin_Bass "Kevin Bass"). Minor league player [Bill
Doran](/wiki/Bill_Doran_\(second_baseman\) "Bill Doran \(second baseman\)")
was called up in September. Bass also got a look in the outfield. The Astros
finished fourth in the west, but new talent was starting to appear.[6]

Before the [1983 season](/wiki/1983_Houston_Astros_season "1983 Houston Astros
season"), the Astros traded [Danny Heep](/wiki/Danny_Heep "Danny Heep") to the
Mets for pitcher [Mike Scott](/wiki/Mike_Scott_\(baseball\) "Mike Scott
\(baseball\)"), a 28-year-old who had struggled with New York. [Art
Howe](/wiki/Art_Howe "Art Howe") sat out the 1983 season with an injury,
forcing [Phil Garner](/wiki/Phil_Garner "Phil Garner") to third and [Ray
Knight](/wiki/Ray_Knight "Ray Knight") to first. Doran took over at second,
becoming the everyday second baseman for the next seven seasons.[41] The
Astros finished third in the National League West.[6] The [1984
season](/wiki/1984_Houston_Astros_season "1984 Houston Astros season") started
off badly when shortstop [Dickie Thon](/wiki/Dickie_Thon "Dickie Thon") was
hit in the head by a pitch and was lost for the season. In September, the
Astros called up rookie [Glenn Davis](/wiki/Glenn_Davis_\(baseball\) "Glenn
Davis \(baseball\)") after he posted impressive numbers in AAA. The Astros
finished in second place. In [1985](/wiki/1985_Houston_Astros_season "1985
Houston Astros season"), [Mike Scott](/wiki/Mike_Scott_\(baseball\) "Mike
Scott \(baseball\)") learned a new pitch, the split-finger fastball. Scott,
who was coming off of a 5–11 season, had found his new pitch and would become
one of Houston's most celebrated hurlers. In June, Davis made the starting
lineup at first base, adding power to the team. In September, [Joe
Niekro](/wiki/Joe_Niekro "Joe Niekro") was traded to the Yankees for two minor
league pitchers and lefty [Jim Deshaies](/wiki/Jim_Deshaies "Jim Deshaies").
The Astros finished in fourth place in 1985.[6]

### 1986: Lighting a
Fire[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: 1986: Lighting a Fire")]

After finishing fourth in 1985, the Astros fired general manager [Al
Rosen](/wiki/Al_Rosen "Al Rosen") and manager [Bob Lillis](/wiki/Bob_Lillis
"Bob Lillis"). The former was supplanted by [Dick
Wagner](/wiki/Dick_Wagner_\(baseball\) "Dick Wagner \(baseball\)"), the man
whose [Reds](/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds "Cincinnati Reds") defeated the Astros to
win the 1979 NL West title. The latter was replaced by [Hal
Lanier](/wiki/Hal_Lanier "Hal Lanier") who, like his manager mentor in St.
Louis, [Whitey Herzog](/wiki/Whitey_Herzog "Whitey Herzog"), had a hard-nosed
approach to managing and espoused a playing style that focused on pitching,
defense, and speed rather than home runs to win games. This style of baseball,
known as [Whiteyball](/wiki/Whiteyball "Whiteyball"), took advantage of
stadiums with deep fences and artificial turf, both of which were
characteristics of the Astrodome. Lanier's style of baseball took Houston by
storm. Before Lanier took over, fans were accustomed to Houston's occasional
slow starts, but with Lanier leading the way, Houston got off to a hot start,
winning 13 of their first 19 contests.[6][42][43]

Prior to the start of the season the Astros acquired outfielder [Billy
Hatcher](/wiki/Billy_Hatcher "Billy Hatcher") from the Cubs for [Jerry
Mumphrey](/wiki/Jerry_Mumphrey "Jerry Mumphrey"). Lainer also made a change in
the pitching staff, going with a three-man rotation to start the season. This
allowed Lanier to keep his three starters ([Nolan Ryan](/wiki/Nolan_Ryan
"Nolan Ryan"), [Bob Knepper](/wiki/Bob_Knepper "Bob Knepper"), and [Mike
Scott](/wiki/Mike_Scott_\(baseball\) "Mike Scott \(baseball\)")) sharp and to
slowly work in rookie hurler [Jim Deshaies](/wiki/Jim_Deshaies "Jim
Deshaies"). [Bill Doran](/wiki/Bill_Doran_\(second_baseman\) "Bill Doran
\(second baseman\)") and [Glenn Davis](/wiki/Glenn_Davis_\(baseball\) "Glenn
Davis \(baseball\)") held down the right side of the field but Lainer rotated
the left side. [Denny Walling](/wiki/Denny_Walling "Denny Walling") and [Craig
Reynolds](/wiki/Craig_Reynolds_\(baseball\) "Craig Reynolds \(baseball\)")
faced the right-handed pitchers while [Phil Garner](/wiki/Phil_Garner "Phil
Garner") and [Dickie Thon](/wiki/Dickie_Thon "Dickie Thon") batted against
left-handers. Lainer knew the Astros had talent and he put it to work.[6][44]

The Astrodome was host to the [1986 All-Star
Game](/wiki/1986_Major_League_Baseball_All-Star_Game "1986 Major League
Baseball All-Star Game") in which Astros [Mike
Scott](/wiki/Mike_Scott_\(baseball\) "Mike Scott \(baseball\)"), [Kevin
Bass](/wiki/Kevin_Bass "Kevin Bass"), [Glenn
Davis](/wiki/Glenn_Davis_\(baseball\) "Glenn Davis \(baseball\)"), and [Dave
Smith](/wiki/Dave_Smith_\(pitcher,_born_1955\) "Dave Smith \(pitcher, born
1955\)") represented the host field. The Astros kept pace with the NL West
after the All-Star break. They went on a streak of five straight come-from-
behind wins. Houston swept a key 3-game series over the [San Francisco
Giants](/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants "San Francisco Giants") in late September
to clinch the division title. [Mike Scott](/wiki/Mike_Scott_\(baseball\) "Mike
Scott \(baseball\)") took the mound in the final game of the series and
pitched a no-hitter – the only time in MLB history that any division was
clinched via a no-hitter. Scott would finish the season with an 18–10 record
and a [Cy Young Award](/wiki/Cy_Young_Award "Cy Young Award").[6][45][46]

The [1986 National League Championship
Series](/wiki/1986_National_League_Championship_Series "1986 National League
Championship Series") against the [New York Mets](/wiki/New_York_Mets "New
York Mets") was noted for great drama and is considered one of the best
postseason series ever.[_[by
whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] In Game 3, the Astros were ahead
at [Shea Stadium](/wiki/Shea_Stadium "Shea Stadium"), 5–4, in the bottom of
the 9th when closer [Dave Smith](/wiki/Dave_Smith_\(pitcher,_born_1955\) "Dave
Smith \(pitcher, born 1955\)") gave up a two-run home run to [Lenny
Dykstra](/wiki/Lenny_Dykstra "Lenny Dykstra"), giving the Mets a dramatic 6–5
win.

However, the signature game of the series was Game 6. Needing a win to get to
Mike Scott (who had been dominant in the series) in Game 7, the Astros jumped
off to a 3–0 lead in the first inning but neither team would score again until
the 9th inning. In the 9th, starting pitcher [Bob Knepper](/wiki/Bob_Knepper
"Bob Knepper") would give up two runs, and once again the Astros would look to
Dave Smith to close it out. However, Smith would walk [Gary
Carter](/wiki/Gary_Carter "Gary Carter") and [Darryl
Strawberry](/wiki/Darryl_Strawberry "Darryl Strawberry"), giving up a
sacrifice fly to [Ray Knight](/wiki/Ray_Knight "Ray Knight"), tying the game.
Despite having the go-ahead runs on base, Smith was able to escape the inning
without any further damage.

There was no scoring until the 14th inning when the Mets would take the lead
on a [Wally Backman](/wiki/Wally_Backman "Wally Backman") single and an error
by left fielder [Billy Hatcher](/wiki/Billy_Hatcher "Billy Hatcher"). The
Astros would get the run back in the bottom of the 14th when Hatcher (in a
classic goat-to-hero-conversion-moment) hit one of the most dramatic home runs
in [NLCS](/wiki/National_League_Championship_Series "National League
Championship Series") history, off the left field foul pole. In the 16th
inning, Darryl Strawberry doubled to lead off the inning and Ray Knight drove
him home in the next at-bat. The Mets would score a total of three runs in the
inning to take what appeared an insurmountable 7–4 lead. With their season on
the line, the Astros would nonetheless rally for two runs to come to within
7–6. Kevin Bass came up with the tying and winning runs on base; however
[Jesse Orosco](/wiki/Jesse_Orosco "Jesse Orosco") would strike him out, ending
the game. At the time the 16-inning game held the record for the longest in
MLB postseason history. The Mets won the series, 4-2.

### 1987–1990: Out with the old, in with the
new[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: 1987–1990: Out with the old, in with the new")]

After the 1986 season, the team had difficulty finding success again. Several
changes occurred. The "rainbow" uniforms were phased out, the team electing to
keep a five-stripe "rainbow" design on the sleeves. From 1987 to 1993, the
Astros wore the same uniform for both home and away games; the only team in
Major League Baseball to do so during that period.[47] Its favorites [Nolan
Ryan](/wiki/Nolan_Ryan "Nolan Ryan") and [José Cruz](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Cruz
"José Cruz") [48] moved on and the team entered a rebuilding phase. [Craig
Biggio](/wiki/Craig_Biggio "Craig Biggio") debuted in June 1988, joining new
prospects [Ken Caminiti](/wiki/Ken_Caminiti "Ken Caminiti") and [Gerald
Young](/wiki/Gerald_Young_\(baseball\) "Gerald Young \(baseball\)"). Biggio
would become the everyday catcher by 1990. A trade acquiring [Jeff
Bagwell](/wiki/Jeff_Bagwell "Jeff Bagwell") in exchange for [Larry
Andersen](/wiki/Larry_Andersen "Larry Andersen") would become one of the
biggest deals in Astros history. Glenn Davis was traded to
[Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore") for [Curt
Schilling](/wiki/Curt_Schilling "Curt Schilling"), [Pete
Harnisch](/wiki/Pete_Harnisch "Pete Harnisch") and [Steve
Finley](/wiki/Steve_Finley "Steve Finley") in 1990.1990–1999: Fine tuning

The early 1990s were marked by the Astros' growing discontent with their home,
the Astrodome. After the Astrodome was renovated for the primary benefit of
the [NFL](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League")'s
[Houston Oilers](/wiki/Houston_Oilers "Houston Oilers") (who shared the
Astrodome with the Astros since the 1960s), the Astros began to grow
increasingly disenchanted with the facility. Faced with declining attendance
at the Astrodome and the inability of management to obtain a new stadium, in
the [1991](/wiki/1991_in_baseball "1991 in baseball") off-season Astros
management announced its intention to sell the team and move the franchise to
the Washington, D.C. area. However, the move was not approved by other
National League owners, thus compelling the Astros to remain in Houston.
Shortly thereafter, McMullen (who also owned the
[NHL](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League")'s [New Jersey
Devils](/wiki/New_Jersey_Devils "New Jersey Devils")) sold the team to Texas
businessman [Drayton McLane](/wiki/Drayton_McLane,_Jr. "Drayton McLane, Jr.")
in 1993, who committed to keeping the team in Houston.

Shortly after McLane's arrival, which coincided with the maturation of Bagwell
and Biggio, the Astros began to show signs of consistent success. After
finishing second in their division in 1994 (in a [strike
year](/wiki/1994%E2%80%9395_Major_League_Baseball_strike "1994–95 Major League
Baseball strike")), 1995, and 1996, the Astros won consecutive division titles
in 1997, 1998, and 1999. In the 1998 season, the Astros set a team record with
102 victories. However, each of these titles was followed by a first-round
playoff elimination, in [1998](/wiki/1998_National_League_Division_Series
"1998 National League Division Series") by the [San Diego
Padres](/wiki/San_Diego_Padres "San Diego Padres") and in
[1997](/wiki/1997_National_League_Division_Series "1997 National League
Division Series") and [1999](/wiki/1999_National_League_Division_Series "1999
National League Division Series") against the [Atlanta
Braves](/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta Braves"). The manager of these title
teams was [Larry Dierker](/wiki/Larry_Dierker "Larry Dierker"), who had
previously been a broadcaster and pitcher for the Astros. During this period,
Bagwell, Biggio, [Derek Bell](/wiki/Derek_Bell_\(baseball\) "Derek Bell
\(baseball\)"), and Sean Berry earned the collective nickname "The Killer Bs".
In later seasons, the name came to include other Astros, especially [Lance
Berkman](/wiki/Lance_Berkman "Lance Berkman").[49]

Coinciding with the change in ownership, the team switched uniforms and team
colors after the [1993](/wiki/1993_in_baseball "1993 in baseball") season in
order to go for a new, more serious image. The team's trademark rainbow
uniforms were retired, and the team's colors changed to midnight blue and
metallic gold. The "Astros" font on the team logo was changed to a more
aggressive one, and the team's traditional star logo was changed to a
stylized, "flying" star with an open left end. It marked the first time since
the team's inception that orange was not part of the team's colors. Despite
general agreement that the rainbow uniforms identified with the team had
become tired (and looked too much like a minor league team according to the
new owners), the new uniforms and caps were never especially popular with many
Astros fans.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/HOU_1078.gif/220px-
HOU_1078.gif)](/wiki/File:HOU_1078.gif)

[](/wiki/File:HOU_1078.gif "Enlarge")

Astros logo, 1994–1999

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Astros_clinch_playoff_berth%21.jpg/300px-
Astros_clinch_playoff_berth%21.jpg)](/wiki/File:Astros_clinch_playoff_berth!.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Astros_clinch_playoff_berth!.jpg "Enlarge")

Final Astros regular season game in the Astrodome on October 3, 1999

Off the field, in 1994, the Astros hired one of the first [African
American](/wiki/African_American "African American") general managers, former
franchise player [Bob Watson](/wiki/Bob_Watson "Bob Watson"). Watson would
leave the Astros after the 1995 season to become general manager of the [New
York Yankees](/wiki/New_York_Yankees "New York Yankees") and helped to lead
the Yankees to a [World Championship](/wiki/1996_World_Series "1996 World
Series") in 1996. He would be replaced by [Gerry
Hunsicker](/wiki/Gerry_Hunsicker "Gerry Hunsicker"), who until 2004 would
continue to oversee the building of the Astros into one of the better and most
consistent organizations in the Major Leagues.

However, in 1996, the Astros again nearly left Houston. By the mid-1990s,
McLane (like McMullen before him) wanted his team out of the Astrodome and was
asking the city to build the Astros a new stadium. When things did not
progress quickly toward that end, he put the team up for sale. He had nearly
finalized a deal to sell the team to businessman William Collins, who planned
to move them to [Northern Virginia](/wiki/Northern_Virginia "Northern
Virginia"). However, Collins was having difficulty finding a site for a
stadium himself, so Major League owners stepped in and forced McLane to give
Houston another chance to grant his stadium wish. Houston voters, having
already lost the [Houston Oilers](/wiki/Houston_Oilers "Houston Oilers") in a
similar situation, responded positively via a stadium referendum and the
Astros stayed put.

### 2000–2004: New
stadium[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: 2000–2004: New stadium")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Houston_Astros_Logo.svg/220px-
Houston_Astros_Logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Houston_Astros_Logo.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Houston_Astros_Logo.svg "Enlarge")

Astros logo, 2000–2012

The 2000 season saw a move to a new stadium. Originally to be named _The
Ballpark at Union Station_ due to being located on the site of [Union Station
(Houston)](/wiki/Union_Station_\(Houston\) "Union Station \(Houston\)"), it
was renamed _[Enron Field](/wiki/Enron_Field "Enron Field")_ by the season
opening after the naming rights were sold to energy corporation
[Enron](/wiki/Enron "Enron"). The stadium was to feature a retractable roof, a
particularly useful feature with unpredictable Houston weather. The ballpark
also featured more intimate surroundings than the Astrodome. In 2002, naming
rights were purchased by Houston-based [Minute Maid](/wiki/Minute_Maid "Minute
Maid"), after [Enron](/wiki/Enron "Enron") went bankrupt. The park was built
on the grounds of the old [Union Station](/wiki/Union_Station_\(Houston\)
"Union Station \(Houston\)"). A locomotive moves across the outfield and
whistles after home runs, paying homage to a Houston history which had eleven
railroad company lines running through the city by 1860. The ballpark
previously contained quirks such as "Tal's Hill", which was a hill in deep
center field on which a flagpole stood, all in fair territory. Tal's Hill was
replaced in the 2016–2017 offseason. The wall was moved in to 409 feet, which
the team hoped would generate more home runs. A similar feature was located in
[Crosley Field](/wiki/Crosley_Field "Crosley Field"). Over the years, many
highlight reel catches have been made by center fielders running up the hill
to make catches. With the change in location also came a change in attire.
Gone were the blue and gold uniforms of the 1990s in favor a more
"[retro](/wiki/Retro "Retro")" look with pinstripes, a traditional baseball
font, and the colors of brick red, sand and black. These colors were chosen
because ownership originally wanted to rename the team the **Houston
Diesels**.[50] The "shooting star" logo was modified but still retained its
definitive look.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Minute_Maid_Park_2010.JPG/220px-
Minute_Maid_Park_2010.JPG)](/wiki/File:Minute_Maid_Park_2010.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Minute_Maid_Park_2010.JPG "Enlarge")

The Astros moved into Minute Maid Park in 2000

After two fairly successful seasons without a playoff appearance, the Astros
were early favorites to win the 2004 NL pennant. They added star pitcher [Andy
Pettitte](/wiki/Andy_Pettitte "Andy Pettitte") to a roster that already
included standouts like [Lance Berkman](/wiki/Lance_Berkman "Lance Berkman")
and [Jeff Kent](/wiki/Jeff_Kent "Jeff Kent") as well as veterans Bagwell and
Biggio. [Roger Clemens](/wiki/Roger_Clemens "Roger Clemens"), who had retired
after the [2003](/wiki/2003_in_baseball "2003 in baseball") season with the
[New York Yankees](/wiki/New_York_Yankees "New York Yankees"), agreed to join
former teammate Pettitte on the Astros for 2004. The one-year deal included
unique conditions, such as the option for Clemens to stay home in Houston on
select road trips when he wasn't scheduled to pitch. Despite the early
predictions for success, the Astros had a mediocre 44–44 record at the All-
Star break. A lack of run production and a poor record in close games were
major issues. After being booed at the 2004 [All-Star
Game](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_All-Star_Game "Major League Baseball All-
Star Game") held in Houston, manager [Jimy Williams](/wiki/Jimy_Williams "Jimy
Williams") was fired and replaced by [Phil Garner](/wiki/Phil_Garner "Phil
Garner"), a star on the division-winning 1986 Astros. The Astros enjoyed a
46–26 record in the second half of the season under Garner and earned the NL
wild card spot. The Astros defeated the [Braves](/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta
Braves") 3–2 in the [Division
Series](/wiki/2004_National_League_Division_Series "2004 National League
Division Series"), but would lose the [National League Championship
Series](/wiki/2004_National_League_Championship_Series "2004 National League
Championship Series") to the [St. Louis Cardinals](/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals
"St. Louis Cardinals") in seven games. Clemens earned a record seventh Cy
Young Award in 2004. Additionally, the mid-season addition of [Carlos
Beltrán](/wiki/Carlos_Beltr%C3%A1n "Carlos Beltrán") in a trade with the
[Kansas City Royals](/wiki/Kansas_City_Royals "Kansas City Royals") helped the
Astros tremendously in their playoff run. Despite midseason trade rumors,
Beltrán would prove instrumental to the team's hopes, hitting eight home runs
in the postseason. Though he had asserted a desire to remain with the Astros,
Beltrán signed a long-term contract with the [New York
Mets](/wiki/New_York_Mets "New York Mets") on January 9, 2005.

### 2005: First World Series in
Texas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: 2005: First World Series in Texas")]

Main article: [2005 Houston Astros season](/wiki/2005_Houston_Astros_season
"2005 Houston Astros season")

In 2005, the Astros started poorly and found themselves with a 15-30 record in
late May. The [Houston Chronicle](/wiki/Houston_Chronicle "Houston Chronicle")
had written them off with a tombstone emblazoned with "RIP 2005 Astros".
However, from that low point until the end of July, Houston went 42–17 and
found themselves in the lead for an NL wild card spot. July saw the best
single month record in the club's history at 22-7. Offensive production had
increased greatly after a slow start in the first two months. The Astros had
also developed an excellent pitching staff, anchored by [Roy
Oswalt](/wiki/Roy_Oswalt "Roy Oswalt") (20–12, 2.94), [Andy
Pettitte](/wiki/Andy_Pettitte "Andy Pettitte") (17–9, 2.39), and [Roger
Clemens](/wiki/Roger_Clemens "Roger Clemens") (13–8 with a league-low ERA of
only 1.87). The contributions of the other starters—[Brandon
Backe](/wiki/Brandon_Backe "Brandon Backe") (10–8, 4.76) and rookie starters
[Ezequiel Astacio](/wiki/Ezequiel_Astacio "Ezequiel Astacio") (3–6, 5.67) and
[Wandy Rodríguez](/wiki/Wandy_Rodr%C3%ADguez "Wandy Rodríguez") (10–10,
5.53)—were less remarkable, but enough to push the Astros into position for a
playoff run. The Astros won a wild card berth on the final day of the regular
season, becoming the first team since the world champion 1914 Boston Braves to
qualify for the postseason after being 15 games under .500.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The Astros won the [National League Division
Series](/wiki/2005_National_League_Division_Series "2005 National League
Division Series") against the [Atlanta Braves](/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta
Braves"), 3-1, with a game four that set postseason records for most innings
(18), most players used by a single team (23), and longest game time (5 hours
and 50 minutes). Trailing by a score of 6-1, [Lance
Berkman](/wiki/Lance_Berkman "Lance Berkman") hit an eighth inning grand slam
to narrow the score to 6–5. In the bottom of the ninth, catcher [Brad
Ausmus](/wiki/Brad_Ausmus "Brad Ausmus"), hit a game tying home run that
allowed the game to continue in extra innings. In the bottom of the tenth
inning, Luke Scott hit a blast to left field that had home run distance, but
was inches foul. This game remained scoreless for the next eight innings. In
the top of the fifteenth inning, Roger Clemens made only his second career
relief appearance, pitching three shutout innings, notably striking out [Julio
Franco](/wiki/Julio_Franco "Julio Franco"), at the time the oldest player in
the MLB at 47 years old; Clemens was himself 43. In the bottom of the
eighteenth inning, Clemens came to bat again, indicating that he would be
pitching in the nineteenth inning, if it came to that. Clemens struck out, but
the next batter, [Chris Burke](/wiki/Chris_Burke_\(baseball\) "Chris Burke
\(baseball\)"), hit a home run to left field for the Astros win, 7–6. Oddly
enough, a fan in the "Crawford Boxes" in left field had previously caught
Berkman's grand slam and this same fan caught Burke's home run.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
[National League Championship
Series](/wiki/2005_National_League_Championship_Series "2005 National League
Championship Series") featured a rematch of the [2004
NLCS](/wiki/2004_National_League_Championship_Series "2004 National League
Championship Series"). The Astros lost the first game in [St.
Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis"), but would win the next three games, with
Roy Oswalt getting the win. Though the Astros were poised to close out the
series in Game Five in Houston, Brad Lidge gave up a monstrous two-out three-
run home run to [Albert Pujols](/wiki/Albert_Pujols "Albert Pujols"), forcing
the series to a sixth game in St. Louis, where the Astros clinched a World
Series appearance. [Roy Oswalt](/wiki/Roy_Oswalt "Roy Oswalt") was named NLCS
MVP, having gone 2–0 with a 1.29 ERA in the series. Current honorary NL
President William Y. Giles presented the league champion Astros with the
Warren C. Giles Trophy. Warren Giles, William's father and President of the
National League from [1951](/wiki/1951_in_baseball "1951 in baseball") to
[1969](/wiki/1969_in_baseball "1969 in baseball"), had awarded an MLB
franchise to the city of Houston in 1960.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The Astros faced the [Chicago White Sox](/wiki/Chicago_White_Sox "Chicago
White Sox") in the [World Series](/wiki/2005_World_Series "2005 World
Series"). Chicago had been considered the slight favorite but would win all
four games, the first two at [U.S. Cellular Field](/wiki/U.S._Cellular_Field
"U.S. Cellular Field") in [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago") and the final two
in Houston. Game 3 marked the first World Series game held in the state of
Texas, and was the longest game in World Series history, lasting 5 hours and
41 minutes.

This World Series was marked by a controversy involving the Minute Maid Park
roof. MLB & Commissioner Bud Selig insisted that the Astros must play with the
roof open which mitigated the intensity and enthusiasm of the cheering Astros
fans.[51]

### 2006–2010: The
decline[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: 2006–2010: The decline")]

In the 2006 offseason, the team signed Preston Wilson and moved Berkman to
first base, ending the long tenure of Jeff Bagwell. The Astros renewed the
contract with Clemens and traded two minor league prospects to the [Tampa Bay
Devil Rays](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Devil_Rays "Tampa Bay Devil Rays") for left-handed
hitter [Aubrey Huff](/wiki/Aubrey_Huff "Aubrey Huff"). By August, Preston
Wilson complained about his playing time after the return of [Luke
Scott](/wiki/Luke_Scott "Luke Scott") from AAA Round Rock. The Astros released
Wilson and he was signed by St. Louis. A dramatic season end included wins in
10 of their last 12 games, but the Astros missed a playoff appearance when
they lost the final game of the season to the Atlanta Braves.

On October 31, the Astros declined a contract option on [Jeff
Bagwell](/wiki/Jeff_Bagwell "Jeff Bagwell") for 2007, ending his 15-year
Astros career and leading to his retirement. [Roger
Clemens](/wiki/Roger_Clemens "Roger Clemens") and [Andy
Pettitte](/wiki/Andy_Pettitte "Andy Pettitte") filed for free agency. On
December 12, the Astros traded [Willy Taveras](/wiki/Willy_Taveras "Willy
Taveras"), [Taylor Buchholz](/wiki/Taylor_Buchholz "Taylor Buchholz"), and
[Jason Hirsh](/wiki/Jason_Hirsh "Jason Hirsh") to the [Colorado
Rockies](/wiki/Colorado_Rockies "Colorado Rockies") for Rockies pitchers
[Jason Jennings](/wiki/Jason_Jennings "Jason Jennings") and [Miguel
Asencio](/wiki/Miguel_Asencio "Miguel Asencio"). A trade with the White Sox,
involving the same three Astros in exchange for Jon Garland, had been nixed a
few days earlier when Buchholz reportedly failed a physical. In the end,
Taveras continued to develop and Hirsh had a strong 2007 rookie campaign,
while Jennings was often injured and generally ineffective.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Orlando_Palmeiro_2007.jpg/220px-
Orlando_Palmeiro_2007.jpg)](/wiki/File:Orlando_Palmeiro_2007.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Orlando_Palmeiro_2007.jpg "Enlarge")

Astros' outfielder [Orlando Palmeiro](/wiki/Orlando_Palmeiro "Orlando
Palmeiro"), 2007

On April 28, 2007, the Astros purchased the contract of top minor league
prospect [Hunter Pence](/wiki/Hunter_Pence "Hunter Pence"). He debuted that
night, getting a hit and scoring a run. By May 2007, the Astros had suffered
one of their worst recent losing streaks (10 games). On June 28, second
baseman [Craig Biggio](/wiki/Craig_Biggio "Craig Biggio") became the 27th MLB
player to accrue 3,000 career hits. Biggio needed three hits to reach 3,000
and on that night he had five hits. That night, [Carlos Lee](/wiki/Carlos_Lee
"Carlos Lee") hit a towering walk-off grand slam in the eleventh inning. Lee
later quipped to the newsmedia that "he had hit a walk-off grand slam and he
got second billing", considering Biggio's achievement. On July 24, Biggio
announced that he would retire at the end of the season. He hit a grand slam
in that night's game which broke a 3–3 tie and led to an Astros win. In
Biggio's last at bat, he grounded out to Chipper Jones of the Atlanta Braves.

On September 20, [Ed Wade](/wiki/Ed_Wade "Ed Wade") was named [General
Manager](/wiki/General_Manager "General Manager"). In his first move, he
traded [Jason Lane](/wiki/Jason_Lane "Jason Lane") to the Padres on September
24. On September 30, Craig Biggio retired after twenty years with the team. In
November, the Astros traded RHP [Brad Lidge](/wiki/Brad_Lidge "Brad Lidge")
and SS [Eric Bruntlett](/wiki/Eric_Bruntlett "Eric Bruntlett") to the
Philadelphia Phillies for OF [Michael Bourn](/wiki/Michael_Bourn "Michael
Bourn"), RHP [Geoff Geary](/wiki/Geoff_Geary "Geoff Geary"), and minor leaguer
[Mike Costanzo](/wiki/Mike_Costanzo "Mike Costanzo"). [Utility
player](/wiki/Utility_player_\(baseball\) "Utility player \(baseball\)") [Mark
Loretta](/wiki/Mark_Loretta "Mark Loretta") accepted Houston's salary
arbitration and [Kazuo Matsui](/wiki/Kazuo_Matsui "Kazuo Matsui") finalized a
$16.5 million, three-year contract with the team. In December the Astros
traded OF [Luke Scott](/wiki/Luke_Scott "Luke Scott"), RHP [Matt
Albers](/wiki/Matt_Albers "Matt Albers"), RHP [Dennis
Sarfate](/wiki/Dennis_Sarfate "Dennis Sarfate"), LHP [Troy
Patton](/wiki/Troy_Patton "Troy Patton"), and minor-league 3B [Mike
Costanzo](/wiki/Mike_Costanzo "Mike Costanzo"), to the [Baltimore
Orioles](/wiki/Baltimore_Orioles "Baltimore Orioles") for SS [Miguel
Tejada](/wiki/Miguel_Tejada "Miguel Tejada"). On December 14, they sent
infielder [Chris Burke](/wiki/Chris_Burke_\(baseball\) "Chris Burke
\(baseball\)"), RHP [Juan Gutiérrez](/wiki/Juan_Guti%C3%A9rrez_\(baseball\)
"Juan Gutiérrez \(baseball\)"), and RHP [Chad Qualls](/wiki/Chad_Qualls "Chad
Qualls") to the Arizona Diamondbacks for RHP [José
Valverde](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Valverde "José Valverde"). On December 27, the
Astros came to terms on a deal with All-star, Gold Glove winner [Darin
Erstad](/wiki/Darin_Erstad "Darin Erstad").

In January and February 2008, the Astros signed [Brandon
Backe](/wiki/Brandon_Backe "Brandon Backe"), [Ty Wigginton](/wiki/Ty_Wigginton
"Ty Wigginton"), [Dave Borkowski](/wiki/Dave_Borkowski "Dave Borkowski") and
[Shawn Chacón](/wiki/Shawn_Chac%C3%B3n "Shawn Chacón") to one-year deals. The
starting rotation would feature [Roy Oswalt](/wiki/Roy_Oswalt "Roy Oswalt")
and Brandon Backe as numbers one and two. [Wandy
Rodríguez](/wiki/Wandy_Rodr%C3%ADguez "Wandy Rodríguez"), Chacón and [Chris
Sampson](/wiki/Chris_Sampson "Chris Sampson") rounded out the bottom three
slots in the rotation. [Woody Williams](/wiki/Woody_Williams "Woody Williams")
had retired after a 0–4 spring training and [Jason
Jennings](/wiki/Jason_Jennings "Jason Jennings") was now with Texas. On the
other side of the roster, the Astros would start without Kazuo Matsui, who was
on a minor league rehab assignment after a spring training injury.

The Astros regressed in 2008 and 2009, finishing with records of 86–75 and
74–88, respectively. Manager [Cecil Cooper](/wiki/Cecil_Cooper "Cecil Cooper")
was fired after the 2009 season.

### 2010–2014: 100-loss seasons, move to the AL West and
rebuilding[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: 2010–2014: 100-loss seasons, move to the AL West and
rebuilding")]

The 2010 season was the first season as Astros manager for [Brad
Mills](/wiki/Brad_Mills_\(manager\) "Brad Mills \(manager\)"), who was
previously the bench coach of the [Boston Red Sox](/wiki/Boston_Red_Sox
"Boston Red Sox"). The Astros struggled throughout a season that was marked by
trade-deadline deals that sent longtime Astros to other teams. On July 29, the
Astros' ace starting pitcher, [Roy Oswalt](/wiki/Roy_Oswalt "Roy Oswalt"), was
dealt to the [Philadelphia Phillies](/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies "Philadelphia
Phillies") for [J. A. Happ](/wiki/J._A._Happ "J. A. Happ") and two minor
league players.[52][53] On July 31, outfielder [Lance
Berkman](/wiki/Lance_Berkman "Lance Berkman") was traded to the [New York
Yankees](/wiki/New_York_Yankees "New York Yankees") for minor leaguers [Jimmy
Paredes](/wiki/Jimmy_Paredes "Jimmy Paredes") and [Mark
Melancon](/wiki/Mark_Melancon "Mark Melancon").[54][55] The Astros finished
with a record of 76-86.

On July 30, 2011, the Astros traded OF [Hunter Pence](/wiki/Hunter_Pence
"Hunter Pence"), the team's 2010 leader in home runs, to the [Philadelphia
Phillies](/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies "Philadelphia Phillies"). On July 31,
they traded OF [Michael Bourn](/wiki/Michael_Bourn "Michael Bourn") to the
[Atlanta Braves](/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta Braves"). On September 17, the
Astros clinched their first 100-loss season in franchise history, On September
28, the Astros ended the season with an 8–0 home loss to the [St. Louis
Cardinals](/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis Cardinals"). Cardinals pitcher
[Chris Carpenter](/wiki/Chris_Carpenter "Chris Carpenter") pitched a complete
game, two-hit shutout in the game, enabling the Cardinals to win the National
League Wild Card, where they went on to beat the Texas Rangers in the World
Series, with [Lance Berkman](/wiki/Lance_Berkman "Lance Berkman") being a key
player in their championship victory. The Astros finished with a record of
56–106, the worst single-season record in franchise history (a record which
would be broken the following season).

In November 2010, Drayton McLane announced that the Astros were being put up
for sale. McLane stated that because the Astros were one of the few franchises
in Major League Baseball with only one family as the owners, he was planning
his estate. McLane was 75 years old as of November 2011.[56] In March 2011,
local Houston businessman [Jim Crane](/wiki/Jim_Crane "Jim Crane") emerged as
the front-runner to purchase the franchise. In the 1980s, Crane founded an air
freight business which later merged with [CEVA
Logistics](/w/index.php?title=CEVA_Logistics&action=edit&redlink=1 "CEVA
Logistics \(page does not exist\)"), and later founded Crane Capital Group.
McLane and Crane had a previous handshake agreement for the franchise in 2008,
but Crane abruptly changed his mind and broke off discussions. Crane also
attempted to buy the [Chicago Cubs](/wiki/Chicago_Cubs "Chicago Cubs") in 2008
and the [Texas Rangers](/wiki/Texas_Rangers_\(baseball\) "Texas Rangers
\(baseball\)") during their 2010 bankruptcy auction.[57] Crane came under
scrutiny because of previous allegations of discriminatory hiring practices
regarding women and minorities, among other issues. This delayed MLB's
approval process. During the summer of 2011, a frustrated Crane hinted that
the delays might threaten the deal.[58] In October 2011, Crane met personally
with MLB Commissioner [Bud Selig](/wiki/Bud_Selig "Bud Selig"), in a meeting
that was described as "constructive".[59]

On November 15, 2011, it was announced that Crane had agreed to move the
franchise to the American League for the 2013 season. The move was part of an
overall divisional realignment of MLB, with the National and American leagues
each having 15 teams in three geographically balanced divisions. Crane was
given a $70 million concession by MLB for agreeing to the switch; the move was
a condition for the sale to the new ownership group.[60] Two days later, the
Astros were officially sold to Crane after the other owners unanimously voted
in favor of the sale.[2] It was also announced that 2012 would be the last
season for the Astros in the NL.[61] After over fifty years of the Astros
being a part of the National League, this move was unpopular with many Astros
fans.[62][63]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Jose_Altuve_at_MMP_Sept_2013.jpg/220px-
Jose_Altuve_at_MMP_Sept_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jose_Altuve_at_MMP_Sept_2013.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jose_Altuve_at_MMP_Sept_2013.jpg "Enlarge")

Astros second baseman [José Altuve](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Altuve "José Altuve") in
2013

In 2012, the Astros were eliminated from the playoffs before September 5. On
September 27, the Astros named [Bo Porter](/wiki/Bo_Porter "Bo Porter") to be
the manager for the 2013 season.

On October 3, the Astros ended over 50 years of NL play with a 5–4 loss to the
Chicago Cubs and began to look ahead to join the American League. Winning only
20 road games during the entire season, the Astros finished with a 55–107
record, the worst record in all of Major League Baseball for the 2012 season,
and surpassing the 2011 season for the worst record in Astros history.

On November 2, 2012, the Astros unveiled their new look in preparation for
their move to the American League for the 2013 season. The uniform is navy
blue and orange, going back to the original 1960s team colors, as well as
debuting a new version of the classic navy blue hat with a white "H" over an
orange star.[64]

On November 6, 2012, the Astros hired former Cleveland Indians director of
baseball operations [David Stearns](/wiki/David_Stearns "David Stearns") as
the team's new assistant general manager.[65] The Astros would also go on to
hire former [St. Louis Cardinals](/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis
Cardinals") front office executive [Jeff Luhnow](/wiki/Jeff_Luhnow "Jeff
Luhnow") as their general manager.

The Houston Astros played their first game as an American League team on March
31, 2013, where they were victorious over their in-state division competitor,
the [Texas Rangers](/wiki/Texas_Rangers_\(baseball\) "Texas Rangers
\(baseball\)"), with a score of 8–2.

On September 29, the Astros completed their first year in the American League,
losing 5–1 in a 14 inning game to the New York Yankees. The Astros finished
the season with a 51–111 record (a franchise worst) with a season ending 15
game losing streak, again surpassing their worst record from last season. The
team finished 45 games back out of the division winner [Oakland
Athletics](/wiki/Oakland_Athletics "Oakland Athletics"), further adding to
their futility. This marked three consecutive years that the Astros had lost
more than 100 games in a single season. They also became the first team to
have the first overall pick in the draft three years in a row. They improved
on their season in [2014](/wiki/2014_Houston_Astros_season "2014 Houston
Astros season"), going 70–92, finishing 28 games back over the division winner
[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Angels_of_Anaheim "Los
Angeles Angels of Anaheim"), and placing fourth in the AL West over the Texas
Rangers.

### 2015: Sudden success and a return to the
playoffs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: 2015: Sudden success and a return to the playoffs")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(August 2015)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
After a slow start, the Astros took over first place in the AL West on April
19 and stayed there until shortly before the All-Star Break in mid-July. The
Astros retook first place on July 29, but fell from first on September 15.

In September 2015, four men died who had been closely associated with the
team: Yogi Berra, Gene Elston, Milo Hamilton, and John McMullen. McMullen and
Hamilton passed on the same Thursday, September 17, 2015, Elston on September
5th, and Berra on September 22. McMullen, after being a co-owner of the New
York Yankees, purchased the Astros in 1979. He also brought Nolan Ryan to the
Astros. In 1980, the Astros played the Philadelphia Phillies for the NL
pennant with Gene Elston on the radio. In 1985, McMullen brought Yogi Berra in
to be a bench coach for the new Astros manager Hal Lanier for the 1986 season,
with Milo Hamilton on the radio.

[Dallas Keuchel](/wiki/Dallas_Keuchel "Dallas Keuchel") led the AL with 20
victories, going 15–0 at home, an MLB record. Key additions to the team
included Scott Kazmir and SS [Carlos Correa](/wiki/Carlos_Correa "Carlos
Correa") who hit 22 home runs, being called up in June 2015. 2B [José
Altuve](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Altuve "José Altuve") picked up where he left off as
the star of the Astros' offense. On July 30, the Astros picked up [Mike
Fiers](/wiki/Mike_Fiers "Mike Fiers") and [Carlos
Gómez](/wiki/Carlos_G%C3%B3mez "Carlos Gómez") from the Milwaukee Brewers.
Fiers threw the 11th [no-hitter](/wiki/No-hitter "No-hitter") in Astros
history on August 21 against the LA Dodgers. Houston got the final AL playoff
spot and faced the Yankees in the [Wild Card
Game](/wiki/2015_American_League_Wild_Card_Game "2015 American League Wild
Card Game") on October 6 at New York. They defeated the Yankees 3–0, but lost
to the Kansas City Royals in the [American League Division
Series](/wiki/2015_American_League_Division_Series "2015 American League
Division Series").

The Astros split the first two games of the ALDS best-of-five series in Kansas
City. The Astros won the first game at Minute Maid to take a 2–1 lead in the
ALDS. In game 4, after 7 innings, the Astros had a 6–2 lead. In the top half
of the eighth inning, which took about 45 minutes to end, the Royals had taken
7–6 lead with a series of consecutive base hits. The Astros suffered a 9–6
loss and the ALDS was tied at 2–2. Then the series went back to Kansas City,
