where the Royals clinched the series in the fifth game, 7-2.

### 2016: Inconsistency, missing the playoffs and struggles against the Texas
Rangers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: 2016: Inconsistency, missing the playoffs and struggles against the
Texas Rangers")]

The Astros entered the 2016 season as the favorites to win the AL West after a
promising 2015 season. After a bad start to their season, with Houston going
just 7–17 in April, the Astros bounced back and went on to have a winning
record in their next four months, including an 18–8 record in June. But after
going 12–15 in September, the Astros were eliminated from playoff contention.
They finished in third place in the American League West Division with a final
record of 84–78.

On August 10, 2016 Gómez was designated for assignment by the Astros after a
dreadful campaign with the team. He was released on August 18, 2016. Gomez
finished his Astros career batting a career low average of .210 and only
hitting 5 HR through 85 games with the club. Gómez later signed with division
rival Texas.

The season was marked by the Astros 4–15 record against their in-state
division rival (and eventual division winner) [Texas
Rangers](/wiki/Texas_Rangers_\(baseball\) "Texas Rangers \(baseball\)"). The
Astros finished the 2016 season eleven games behind the Rangers.

### 2017: World Series
champions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: 2017: World Series champions")]

Main article: [2017 World Series](/wiki/2017_World_Series "2017 World Series")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Downtown_Houston_Skyline_During_2017_World_Series.jpg/220px-
Downtown_Houston_Skyline_During_2017_World_Series.jpg)](/wiki/File:Downtown_Houston_Skyline_During_2017_World_Series.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Downtown_Houston_Skyline_During_2017_World_Series.jpg "Enlarge")

Many buildings in the skyline of [Downtown Houston](/wiki/Downtown_Houston
"Downtown Houston") participated in cheering for the Astros during the [2017
World Series](/wiki/2017_World_Series "2017 World Series").

In 2014, _Sports Illustrated_ predicted the Astros would win the 2017 World
Series through their strategic rebuilding process.[66] As of June 9, the
Astros were 41–16, which gave them a 13.5-game lead over the rest of their
division, and they had comfortable possession of the best record in the entire
league. This was the best start in the Astros' 55-year history. As the games
of June 23 concluded, the Astros had an 11.5-game lead over the rest of the
division. The Astros entered the All-Star Break with an American League best
60–29 record and a 16 game lead in the division, although the overall best
record in MLB had just barely slipped to the Dodgers shortly before the All-
Star Break by just one game.

With [Hurricane Harvey](/wiki/Hurricane_Harvey "Hurricane Harvey") causing
massive flooding throughout Houston and southeast Texas, the Astros' three-
game series against the [Texas Rangers](/wiki/Texas_Rangers_\(baseball\)
"Texas Rangers \(baseball\)") for August 29–31, was relocated to [Tropicana
Field](/wiki/Tropicana_Field "Tropicana Field") (home of the [Tampa Bay
Rays](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Rays "Tampa Bay Rays")), in [St.
Petersburg](/wiki/St._Petersburg,_Florida "St. Petersburg, Florida"),
[Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida").[67] The Astros greatly improved against
the Rangers in 2017, going 12–7 against them and winning the season series.

At the August 31 waiver-trade deadline GM Jeff Luhnow acquired veteran
starting pitcher and Cy Young Award winner Justin Verlander to bolster the
starting rotation.[68] Verlander won each of his 5 regular season starts with
the Astros, yielding only 4 runs over this stretch. He carried his success
into the playoffs, posting a record of 4-1 in his 6 starts, and throwing a
complete game shutout in Game 2 of the ALCS. Verlander was named the 2017 ALCS
MVP.[69]

The Astros clinched their first division title as a member of the American
League West division, and first division title overall since 2001. They also
became the first team in Major League history to win three different
divisions: National League West in 1980 and 1986, National League Central from
1997–1999 and 2001, and American League West in 2017. On September 29, the
Astros won their 100th game of the season, the second time the Astros finished
a season with over 100 wins, the first being in 1998. They finished 101–61,
with a 21-game lead in the division, and faced the Red Sox in the first round
of the AL playoffs. The Astros defeated the Red Sox three games to one, and
advanced to the [American League Championship
Series](/wiki/American_League_Championship_Series "American League
Championship Series") against the [New York Yankees](/wiki/New_York_Yankees
"New York Yankees"). The Astros won the ALCS four games to three, and advanced
to the [World Series](/wiki/2017_World_Series "2017 World Series") to play
against the [Los Angeles Dodgers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Dodgers "Los Angeles
Dodgers"). The Astros defeated the Dodgers in the deciding seventh game of the
World Series, winning the first championship in franchise history.[70]

The city of Houston celebrated the team's accomplishment with a parade on the
afternoon of November 3, 2017. Houston's Independent School District gave the
students and teachers the day off to watch the parade.

On November 16, 2017 Jose Altuve was named the American League Most Valuable
Player, capping off a historic season in which he accumulated 200 hits for the
fourth consecutive season, led the majors with a .346 BA, and was the
unquestioned clubhouse leader of the World Series Champions.

## Radio and
television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Radio and television")]

See also: [Houston Astros Radio Network](/wiki/Houston_Astros_Radio_Network
"Houston Astros Radio Network")

As of
2013[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit),
the Astros' new flagship radio station is [KBME](/wiki/KBME_\(AM\) "KBME
\(AM\)"), Sportstalk 790AM (a [Fox Sports Radio](/wiki/Fox_Sports_Radio "Fox
Sports Radio") affiliate), leaving [KTRH](/wiki/KTRH_\(AM\) "KTRH \(AM\)"),
740AM after a partnership with them since 1999 (both stations are owned by
[iHeartMedia](/wiki/IHeartMedia "IHeartMedia")). This change suddenly made it
difficult for listeners outside of Houston itself to hear the Astros, as KTRH
runs 50 kilowatts of power day and night, and KBME runs only five kilowatts.
As a result, KTRH is audible across much of Central, East, and South Texas,
whereas KBME can only be heard in Houston, especially after dark. [Milo
Hamilton](/wiki/Milo_Hamilton "Milo Hamilton"), a veteran voice who was on the
call for [Hank Aaron](/wiki/Hank_Aaron "Hank Aaron")'s 715th career home run
in 1974, retired at the end of the 2012 season, after broadcasting play-by-
play for the Astros since 1985. [Dave Raymond](/wiki/Dave_Raymond "Dave
Raymond") and Brett Dolan shared play-by play duty for road games, while
Raymond additionally worked as Hamilton's color analyst (while Hamilton called
home games only for the past few seasons before his retirement); they were not
retained and instead brought in [Robert
Ford](/wiki/Robert_Ford_\(sportscaster\) "Robert Ford \(sportscaster\)") and
[Steve Sparks](/wiki/Steve_Sparks_\(pitcher,_born_1965\) "Steve Sparks
\(pitcher, born 1965\)") to begin broadcasting for the 2013 season.[77]

Spanish language radio play-by-play is handled by Francisco Romero, and his
play-by-play partner is [Alex Treviño](/wiki/Alex_Trevi%C3%B1o "Alex
Treviño"), a former backup catcher for the club.

During the 2012 season Astros games on television were announced by [Bill
Brown](/wiki/Bill_Brown_\(broadcaster\) "Bill Brown \(broadcaster\)") and [Jim
Deshaies](/wiki/Jim_Deshaies "Jim Deshaies"). In the seven seasons before
then, Astros games were broadcast on television by [Fox Sports
Houston](/wiki/Fox_Sports_Houston "Fox Sports Houston"), with select games
shown on broadcast TV by [KTXH](/wiki/KTXH "KTXH"). As part of a ten-year, $1
billion deal with [Comcast](/wiki/Comcast "Comcast") that includes a majority
stake jointly held by the Astros and the [Houston
Rockets](/wiki/Houston_Rockets "Houston Rockets"), Houston Astros games moved
to the new Comcast SportsNet Houston at the beginning of the 2013 season.[78]
On September 27, 2013 CSN Houston filed for [Chapter 11
Bankruptcy](/wiki/Chapter_11_Bankruptcy "Chapter 11 Bankruptcy") and
surprising the Astros who own the largest stake.[79] After being brought out
of bankruptcy by [DirecTV Sports Networks](/wiki/DirecTV_Sports_Networks
"DirecTV Sports Networks") and [AT&T](/wiki/AT%26T "AT&T"), the channel's name
was changed to Root Sports Southwest then later [AT&T SportsNet
Southwest](/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Southwest "AT&T SportsNet Southwest").

The current television team consists of [Todd Kalas](/wiki/Todd_Kalas "Todd
Kalas") and [Geoff Blum](/wiki/Geoff_Blum "Geoff Blum").

## Mascots[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Houston_Astros&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Mascots")]

Main article: [Orbit (mascot)](/wiki/Orbit_\(mascot\) "Orbit \(mascot\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Orbit_Houston_Astros_mascot_preseason_2014.jpg/220px-
Orbit_Houston_Astros_mascot_preseason_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Orbit_Houston_Astros_mascot_preseason_2014.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Orbit_Houston_Astros_mascot_preseason_2014.jpg "Enlarge")

[Orbit](/wiki/Orbit_\(mascot\) "Orbit \(mascot\)"), Houston Astros mascot from
1990–1999, 2013–present

Orbit is the name given to MLB's Houston Astros mascot, a lime-green outer-
space creature wearing an Astros jersey with antennae extending into
baseballs. Orbit was the team's official mascot from the 1990 through the 1999
seasons until the 2000 season, where Junction Jack was introduced as the
team's mascot with the move from the Astrodome to then Enron Field. Orbit
returned on November 2, 2012 at the unveiling of the Astros new look for their
2013 debut in the American League. The name Orbit pays homage to Houston's
association with NASA and nickname Space City.[80]

The Astros had been represented by a trio of rabbit mascots named Junction
Jack, Jesse and Julie from 2000 through 2012.[81]

In April 1977 the Houston Astros introduced their very first mascot, Chester
Charge. Created by Ed Henderson, Chester Charge was a Texas cavalry soldier on
a horse. Chester appeared on the field at the beginning of each home game,
during the seventh inning stretch and then ran around the bases at the
conclusion of each win. At the blast of a bugle, the scoreboard would light up
and the audience would yell, "Charge!"[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
